content.description: A disk of mass <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> slides with negligible friction to the right with speed <math alttext="v sub i" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>i</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> on a horizontal table. The disk collides elastically with a uniform rod of length <math alttext="l" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mo>ℓ</mo></mstyle></math> that is at rest and free to pivot about one end, as shown in Figure 1 above. The disk rebounds to the left with speed <math alttext="v sub f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the rod rotates with friction and stops at a final angle <math alttext="theta sub f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> from its initial position, as shown in Figure 2.
content.question: What happens to the magnitude of the angular momentum of the disk-rod system with respect to the pivot during the time interval between Figure 1 and Figure 2, and why?

choices.label: It decreases because the disk reverses its direction of motion.
It decreases because an external torque is exerted by friction.
It does not change because there was no angular momentum before the collision.
It does not change because angular momentum was conserved during the collision.

content.answer: It decreases because an external torque is exerted by friction.
